review: I really expected this to be just a little novelty that I would hardly use, but I am shocked to say, I think it has become my primary "TV" watching tool.I have my computer hooked up to my TV, so that has been my default viewing machine for about two years now. But, this little device manages to deliver a better user experience and even a better image that my computer does...I love it, and I really think you will too.The downside:1. Navigating is a little slow. The menus just aren't quite as snappy is I would have expected, but really, that is a minor issue.2. You CANNOT use it at most hotels. Because hotels usually require you to verify terms and conditions via a web browser (which the Fire Stick does NOT have), the Fire Stick basically becomes unusable. Honestly, if they could fix that issue, I'd give them 5 stars, even with the navigation lag...This item is definitely a buy. It's simple to setup (pretty much just plug it in...), it has an amazing picture, and a good selection of apps too. But if you're more of a road warrior, Chromecast is still probably the better fit for you.

author: Amazon Customer "G.Brainard"

review: I have been using the Amazon Fire Stick since it first came out. I love the interface, the ease of setup, the simple remote control, and the easy access to all of the Prime features.Unfortunately, 3 months with 2 different Fire Sticks and several calls to Amazon tech support have revealed major performance problems.First were the hiccups. Video played smoothly, but after a month or so, it started to stutter, regardless of the TV I used, or whether I was watching Amazon Instant, Prime, Netflix or other apps. A couple of calls to tech support got that resolved, then a couple of weeks later it happened again.  Each time involved disconnecting, resetting, etc.Now when I try to use it to play video on my big screen TV, I get audio only, and "DHCP Error" appears on the screen. Again, this is true whether it's purchased videos, Amazon Prime videos, Netflix, etc. Everything was working fine two days ago, but now Amazon tech support says there was an update and my 2011 model 65" TV with 4 HDMI inputs is no longer supported. He said I needed to get a new TV.Really?
